customer_name: Carvalhos Friends of A Feather Inc.
site_name: Carvalho's Friends of a Feather, Inc.

citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
After completing the animal portion of the inspection with the owner, we requested access to all required records. He
informed us that the records were in the office located offsite, and he contacted his partner to ensure we would have
access to the required records. After driving to the office and finding no one there, we called and left messages. After an
additional 45 minutes, no one had arrived or called back so we called and left a message that we were not able to access
the records. APHIS officials must be allowed to examine the records required to be kept by the Act and the regulations in
this part.
Correct from this day forward 27 October, 2023.

The outdoor cassowary enclosure had a 4ft by 8ft section of wall panel, constructed of wire mesh welded to a pipe frame,
that the side and top welds broken away allowing a portion of the panel to be retracted approximately 10 inches from its
support structure, creating a potential head trap. Three bird enclosures had metal clips and eye screws, used to suspend
wood blocks in the enclosure, with blocks chewed away leaving the screw end exposed. The inside of the exterior wall of
the King Vulture enclosure had an approximately 8 inch wide by 6 inch tall area which was flaking, pitted, and rusty.
There were sections of wall in both Eagle owl enclosures with sheets of plywood which had been damaged and broken
leaving sharp jagged points and irregular surfaces in the cage.
The primary enclosure must be constructed and maintained to protect the birds from injury, and all surfaces that come in
contact with the birds must be able to be readily cleaned and sanitized.
Correct by 7 November 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility owner.
Additional Inspectors:
KATHARINE FRANK, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.126(a)(2) 
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
After completing the animal portion of the inspection with the owner, we requested access to all required records. He 
informed us that the records were in the office located offsite, and he contacted his partner to ensure we would have 
access to the required records. After driving to the office and finding no one there, we called and left messages. After an 
additional 45 minutes, no one had arrived or called back so we called and left a message that we were not able to access 
the records. APHIS officials must be allowed to examine the records required to be kept by the Act and the regulations in 
this part. 
 
Correct from this day forward 27 October, 2023. 
3.153(a)(1) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The outdoor cassowary enclosure had a 4ft by 8ft section of wall panel, constructed of wire mesh welded to a pipe frame, 
that the side and top welds broken away allowing a portion of the panel to be retracted approximately 10 inches from its 
support structure, creating a potential head trap. Three bird enclosures had metal clips and eye screws, used to suspend 
wood blocks in the enclosure, with blocks chewed away leaving the screw end exposed. The inside of the exterior wall of 
the King Vulture enclosure had an approximately 8 inch wide by 6 inch tall area which was flaking, pitted, and rusty.  
There were sections of wall in both Eagle owl enclosures with sheets of plywood which had been damaged and broken 
leaving sharp jagged points and irregular surfaces in the cage. 
 
The primary enclosure must be constructed and maintained to protect the birds from injury, and all surfaces that come in 
contact with the birds must be able to be readily cleaned and sanitized.  
 
 Correct by 7 November 2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility owner.

Additional Inspectors: 
KATHARINE FRANK, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
